sections.title: Microphone Level
sections.text:
The electrical signal output directly from a microphone - the weakest signal in the entire audio chain.

**Signal Strength:** Typically -60dBu to -40dBu (extremely weak, measured in millivolts).

**Why So Weak:**
- Sound pressure waves move microphone diaphragm
- Creates very small electrical voltage (millivolts)
- Acoustic to electrical transduction inherently produces tiny signal
- Requires significant amplification to be usable

**Variation by Microphone Type:**
- **Dynamic microphones:** -54 to -60dBV/Pa (less sensitive, need more gain)
- **Condenser microphones:** -34 to -42dBV/Pa (more sensitive, need less gain)
- **Ribbon microphones:** -54 to -60dBV/Pa or lower (least sensitive, need most gain)

**Measured in:** dBu (voltage relative to 0.775V) or dBV (voltage relative to 1V).

**Professional Understanding:** This is the most critical point in signal chain. Any noise introduced here gets amplified by everything downstream. Quality preamp essential for clean signal. Proper gain staging begins at this first stage.

**Comparison:** Approximately 1000 times weaker than line level. Must be brought up to line level (+4dBu professional standard) through preamp.

---

sections.title: Preamp Gain
sections.text:
Amount of amplification applied to microphone signal by preamplifier.

**Gain Range:** Typically 0dB to 70dB available on professional preamps.

**Typical Gain Requirements by Source:**
- **Dynamic microphones on loud sources:** 30-45dB (guitar amp, snare drum)
- **Dynamic microphones on quiet sources:** 45-60dB (soft vocals, quiet acoustic instruments)
- **Condenser microphones on loud sources:** 15-30dB (close-miked vocals, acoustic guitar)
- **Condenser microphones on quiet sources:** 30-45dB (distant acoustic sources, classical)
- **Ribbon microphones:** 50-70dB (very low output, needs excellent preamp)

**Goal:** Bring microphone-level signal to line level (approximately +4dBu or -18dBFS digital).

**Controls:** Usually single knob labeled "Gain," "Trim," or "Input." Some preamps have stepped controls (detented positions) for recall.

**Quality Matters:**
- **Low noise floor:** Critical at high gain settings
- **Wide frequency response:** 20Hz-20kHz ideally
- **Low distortion:** <0.01% THD for clean preamps
- **High headroom:** Prevents overload on loud transients
- **Character:** Clean/transparent vs colored/warm (Neve, API)

**Famous Preamps:**
- **Neve 1073:** Warm British sound, Class A, transformer-coupled ($3,000-5,000)
- **API 512c:** Punchy American sound, discrete op-amp ($1,500-2,000)
- **Universal Audio 610:** Tube warmth, smooth highs ($1,800-2,200)
- **Grace M101:** Ultra-clean, transparent reference ($1,500)
- **SSL VHD:** Versatile, clean to colored modes ($1,200)

**Professional Practice:** Set gain while performer plays loudest part. Watch meter for peaks around -12dB to -6dBFS. Leave 6dB headroom for unexpected peaks.

---

sections.title: Line Level
sections.text:
Standard operating level for professional audio equipment interconnections.

**Professional Standard:** +4dBu (1.228V RMS)
**Consumer Standard:** -10dBV (0.316V RMS)

**Approximately 1000 times stronger than microphone level** - much more robust signal.

**Achieved After:** Microphone preamp amplification (mic level → line level).

**Used For:**
- Equipment interconnections (synth to interface, outboard gear)
- Mixing console signal flow
- Effects sends and returns
- DAW inputs/outputs
- Patch bay connections

**Output Sources:**
- Preamps (after amplifying mic signal)
- Mixers (summed/processed signals)
- Synthesizers, samplers, drum machines
- Effects processors (reverb, delay units)
- Digital converters (D/A output)
- CD/media players

**Why Important:** Most audio processing equipment expects line-level input. Too low = noise, too high = clipping. Plugins in DAW designed for line-level signals.

**Nominal Level:** Allows adequate headroom for signal peaks while maintaining good signal-to-noise ratio.

**Professional Practice:** Understand difference between mic and line level. Never connect line-level output directly to mic input (will overload/clip). Use DI box or pad when necessary.

---

sections.title: Pad (Attenuation)
sections.text:
Switch that reduces input signal level by fixed amount before preamp gain stage.

**Typical Attenuation:** -10dB or -20dB (halves or quarters the signal)

**Location:**
- On microphone itself (switchable pad on mic body)
- On preamp/interface (pad button per channel)
- Sometimes both available

**When to Use:**
- **Very loud sources:** Close-miked kick drum, snare drum, guitar/bass amps at high volume
- **Condenser mics on loud sources:** Prevents capsule overload
- **High-output microphones:** Some mics produce stronger signal
- **Brass instruments:** Trumpet, trombone close-miked
- **Loud vocals:** Screaming, aggressive performances

**How It Works:** Reduces signal before it reaches preamp circuitry, preventing overload of preamp input stage.

**Example Scenario:** Condenser microphone on kick drum. Full signal might overload preamp. Engage -20dB pad, then increase preamp gain to compensate. Result: clean signal without distortion.

**Alternative Solutions:**
- Move microphone farther from source (inverse square law)
- Use less sensitive microphone (dynamic instead of condenser)
- Reduce sound source volume (if possible)

**Professional Practice:** Use pad when seeing preamp overload (distortion) even with gain at minimum. Not substitute for proper mic placement, but essential tool for very loud sources.

---

sections.title: Phantom Power (+48V)
sections.text:
DC voltage supplied through microphone cable to power condenser microphones.

**Standard Voltage:** 48 volts DC (can range 12-48V, but 48V is universal standard)

**Delivery Method:**
- Sent through XLR pins 2 and 3 (positive voltage)
- Returns via pin 1 (ground/shield)
- Balanced delivery (equal voltage on both signal pins)
- Doesn't affect audio signal

**Powers:**
- **All condenser microphones** (unless battery-powered)
- **Active DI boxes** (some models)
- **Active ribbon microphones** (modern designs with internal electronics)

**Safe For:**
- **Dynamic microphones:** Completely ignore phantom power (balanced design rejects it)
- **Passive ribbon microphones (modern):** Most modern ribbons are phantom-safe

**Dangerous For:**
- **Vintage ribbon microphones:** Can damage delicate ribbon element (permanent damage)
- **Some unbalanced equipment:** If incorrectly wired

**Toggle Control:**
- Usually single switch for 2-8 channels (not always individual)
- Some interfaces: individual +48V per channel
- Professional consoles: typically per channel or per group

**Indicator:** Usually red LED when engaged

**Best Practices:**
- **Turn on for condensers:** Required for operation (no phantom power = no signal)
- **Turn off when not needed:** Saves power, prevents accidental damage
- **Check before connecting ribbons:** Vintage ribbons especially vulnerable
- **Mute channel when toggling:** Prevents loud pop in monitors
- **Wait 10 seconds after engaging:** Allows voltage to stabilize

**Troubleshooting:**
- Condenser mic not working? Check phantom power is on
- Condenser sounds weak? Phantom power may not be delivering full 48V (cheap interface)
- Popping sounds when connecting? Mute channel first

**Phantom Power Standards:**
- P48: 48V ±4V, 10mA max current (international standard IEC 61938)
- P24: 24V (less common, some equipment)
- P12: 12V (rare, vintage equipment)

---

sections.title: Impedance Matching
sections.text:
Relationship between source (microphone) output impedance and load (preamp) input impedance.

**Microphone Output Impedance:**
- Low impedance: 50-600Ω (professional standard)
- High impedance: >10,000Ω (vintage mics, guitar pickups)

**Preamp Input Impedance:**
- Professional: 1,000-10,000Ω (typically 1.5kΩ to 2.5kΩ)
- High-Z inputs: >1MΩ (for instruments)

**Matching Rule:** Load impedance should be **5-10 times higher** than source impedance.

**Example:** 200Ω microphone into 2,000Ω preamp input = 10:1 ratio (ideal)

**Why It Matters:**
- **Properly matched:** Maximum power transfer, flat frequency response, low noise, optimal damping
- **Mismatched (load too low):** Loss of level, frequency response changes, increased distortion
- **Mismatched (load too high):** Generally acceptable, minimal effect

**Low Impedance Advantages:**
- Can use long cables (100+ feet) without signal loss
- Better rejection of electromagnetic interference
- Industry standard for professional audio
- Balanced connections (XLR)

**High Impedance Issues:**
- Limited cable length (<20 feet before significant loss)
- Susceptible to noise and interference
- Frequency response degrades with long cables
- Requires direct connection or transformer

**Modern Practice:** All professional microphones are low impedance. All professional preamps have appropriate input impedance. Matching is automatic. Only concern when using vintage equipment or adapting instruments.

**Transformers:** Can match impedances between incompatible devices. Used in some vintage equipment and DI boxes.

---

sections.title: Gain Structure
sections.text:
Optimizing signal levels throughout complete recording chain.

**Complete Chain:** Microphone → Preamp → Converter → DAW → Processing → Output

**Each Stage Affects:**
- Noise floor (cumulative)
- Headroom (available level before clipping)
- Signal-to-noise ratio
- Distortion characteristics

**Goal:** Maximize signal-to-noise ratio while preventing clipping at any stage.

**Proper Gain Structure Process:**

**Stage 1 - Microphone Preamp (most critical):**
- Set gain while performer plays loudest part
- Target: Peaks around -12dB to -6dBFS on interface meter
- Leave 6dB headroom for unexpected peaks
- If clipping: reduce preamp gain (not interface level)

**Stage 2 - Interface Input:**
- Should receive healthy level from preamp
- Most interfaces: unity gain after preamp (no additional gain needed)
- Monitor input level on interface hardware meters

**Stage 3 - DAW Track Input:**
- Confirm proper level on track meter
- Peaks: -12dB to -6dBFS
- Average: around -18dBFS
- Leave headroom for processing

**Stage 4 - Plugin Processing:**
- Plugins expect appropriate input levels
- Some plugins: work better with specific input levels
- Watch output levels after processing
- Maintain headroom

**Stage 5 - Master Bus:**
- Sum of all tracks
- Before mastering: peaks around -6dB to -3dBFS
- Maintain headroom for mastering processing

**Common Mistakes:**
- Recording too hot (clipping, no headroom)
- Recording too quiet (noise becomes audible)
- Adjusting wrong stage (interface gain vs preamp gain)
- Ignoring cumulative gain through processing

**Professional Standard:** Conservative levels throughout. Can always add more gain, cannot remove clipping. Headroom is insurance against disasters.

**Digital vs Analog:** Digital has hard ceiling (0dBFS). Analog has softer clipping. Digital requires more conservative approach.

---

sections.title: Dynamic Microphone (Moving Coil)
sections.text:
**Technology/Operating Principle:**
Electromagnetic induction using moving coil attached to diaphragm. Sound pressure waves move diaphragm → coil moves within magnetic field → generates voltage through electromagnetic induction. Simple, passive design with no active electronics.

**Construction:**
- Diaphragm (very thin plastic/Mylar film)
- Voice coil (fine wire coiled around former)
- Magnet assembly (permanent magnet creating field)
- Case/housing (protects internals)

**Key Characteristics:**
- **Rugged/Durable:** Can handle rough treatment, drops, moisture
- **High SPL handling:** 140dB+ typical (can handle extremely loud sources)
- **No power required:** Works passively (no batteries, no phantom power)
- **Less sensitive:** Than condensers (captures less detail but more focused)
- **Limited frequency response:** Typically 50Hz-15kHz (adequate for most sources)
- **Presence peak:** Usually 3-5kHz for vocal clarity and "bite"
- **High maximum SPL:** Won't distort even with very loud sources

**Frequency Response:**
- Low end: 50-80Hz roll-off (reduces handling noise, rumble)
- Midrange: relatively flat 200Hz-5kHz
- Presence peak: 3-5kHz boost (adds clarity, intelligibility)
- High end: gradual roll-off above 10kHz

**Impedance:** Low (150-600Ω) - professional standard

**Proximity Effect:** Present (bass boost when close, typically 6-12dB at 100Hz when <6 inches)

**Applications:**
- **Live vocals:** Feedback resistant, rugged (SM58 standard)
- **Drums:** High SPL handling (snare, toms, kick - SM57, Beta 52A)
- **Guitar amplifiers:** Can handle volume (SM57 industry standard)
- **Bass amplifiers:** Low-end reproduction
- **High SPL sources:** Brass, loud vocals, percussion
- **Budget recording:** Affordable, versatile
- **Environments:** Where ruggedness matters (touring, clubs)

**Famous Examples:**
- **Shure SM57:** Industry standard instrument mic, $99, found in every studio
- **Shure SM58:** Most popular live vocal mic, $99, nearly indestructible
- **Sennheiser MD421:** Versatile large-diaphragm dynamic, excellent on toms/guitar, $379
- **Electro-Voice RE20:** Broadcast standard, kick drum favorite, reduced proximity effect, $449
- **Shure Beta 57A/58A:** Higher output versions, tighter pattern, $159

**Typical Specifications:**
- Sensitivity: -54dBV/Pa (less sensitive than condenser)
- Max SPL: 140-150dB (extremely loud before distortion)
- Frequency Response: 50Hz-15kHz (±3dB)
- Impedance: 150-300Ω (low, professional)
- Self-noise: N/A (passive, no self-noise)

**Advantages:**
- Extremely rugged and reliable
- No power needed
- High SPL handling
- Less sensitive to room acoustics
- Affordable
- Feedback resistant (live sound)

**Disadvantages:**
- Less detailed than condensers
- Limited high-frequency extension
- Less sensitive (needs more gain)
- Heavier (more mass to move)

**Professional Uses:** First choice for live sound. Studio use for drums, guitar amps, and sources where robustness and high SPL handling needed. SM57 on snare drum is industry standard.

---

sections.title: Condenser Microphone (Large Diaphragm)
sections.text:
**Technology/Operating Principle:**
Capacitor-based transduction. Two plates form capacitor: front plate (diaphragm - movable) and back plate (fixed). Fixed electrical charge applied. Sound pressure moves diaphragm → changes distance between plates → changes capacitance → creates voltage change proportional to sound. Requires active electronics to maintain charge and buffer output signal.

**Construction:**
- Capsule (diaphragm + backplate forming capacitor)
- Polarization circuit (maintains charge - externally or permanently polarized)
- Impedance converter (FET or tube - buffers signal)
- Output transformer (some models - adds character)
- Power required (phantom power or battery)

**Power Requirements:**
- Phantom power: +48V most common (international standard)
- Some models: battery powered (9V internal battery)
- Permanently polarized: still need power for impedance converter

**Key Characteristics:**
- **Very sensitive:** Captures fine detail and nuance
- **Extended frequency response:** 20Hz-20kHz+ (full audible spectrum)
- **Wide dynamic range:** Excellent for studio recording (quiet to loud)
- **Requires phantom power:** +48V standard
- **More fragile:** Sensitive to humidity, shock, vibration
- **Lower max SPL:** 120-135dB typical (140dB with pad engaged)

**Large Diaphragm Specifics:**
- **Diaphragm size:** ≥1 inch (25mm) diameter (typically 1" or 34mm)
- **Character:** Warmer, slightly colored sound (pleasant distortion)
- **Proximity effect:** Present and usable (bass boost when close)
- **Low-end response:** Extended and full
- **Self-noise:** 7-20dB SPL-A typical (slightly higher than small diaphragm)
- **Polar patterns:** Often switchable (cardioid, omni, figure-8)

**Frequency Response:**
- Extended low end: 20Hz (some models down to 10Hz)
- Flat midrange: accurate reproduction
- Extended highs: 20kHz+ (air and detail)
- Presence peak: some models have slight boost 5-10kHz

**Applications:**
- **Studio vocals:** Primary choice (warmth, detail, presence)
- **Voiceover/broadcast:** Clarity and intimacy
- **Acoustic instruments:** Guitar, piano, strings (captures detail)
- **Overhead cymbals:** Smooth, detailed reproduction
- **Room microphones:** Ambient capture in good-sounding rooms
- **Any source:** Requiring detail, warmth, and professional quality

**Famous Examples:**
- **Neumann U87:** Industry standard, versatile, $3,200 (most recorded vocal mic)
- **AKG C414:** Versatile, 9 polar patterns, $1,099 (studio workhorse)
- **Audio-Technica AT4050:** Affordable quality, multi-pattern, $699
- **Rode NT1:** Extremely quiet (4.5dB self-noise), $229 (incredible value)
- **Sony C800G:** High-end vocal mic, tube, $10,000+ (Mariah Carey, Michael Jackson)
- **Neumann U47:** Vintage legend, tube, $8,000+ used (Beatles, Sinatra)
- **Telefunken U47:** Modern reissue, $9,000 (vintage sound, modern reliability)

**Typical Specifications:**
- Sensitivity: -36dBV/Pa (much more sensitive than dynamic)
- Max SPL: 120-135dB without pad, 140-145dB with pad
- Frequency Response: 20Hz-20kHz (±2dB)
- Impedance: 200Ω (low, professional)
- Self-noise: 7-20dB SPL-A (quiet to very quiet)
- Requires: +48V phantom power

**Advantages:**
- Extremely detailed and accurate
- Extended frequency response
- Captures subtle nuances
- Professional sound quality
- Versatile (vocals, instruments, ambience)

**Disadvantages:**
- Requires phantom power
- More fragile (sensitive electronics)
- Lower max SPL (without pad)
- More expensive
- Sensitive to humidity and temperature
- Can capture too much detail (room noise)

**Professional Uses:** Studio standard for vocals. Recording acoustic instruments. Any application where detail and quality paramount. Not typically for live sound (feedback prone, fragile).

---

sections.title: Condenser Microphone (Small Diaphragm)
sections.text:
**Technology/Operating Principle:**
Same capacitor principle as large diaphragm condenser. Smaller diaphragm (less mass) allows faster response to transients.

**Diaphragm Size:** <1 inch (typically 12-18mm diameter) - sometimes called "pencil condensers"

**Key Characteristics:**
- **More accurate:** Flatter frequency response than large diaphragm
- **Extended high frequency:** Excellent high-frequency extension to 20kHz+
- **Faster transient response:** Less mass = quicker response (better for percussive sounds)
- **Lower self-noise:** Typically quieter than large diaphragm (5-15dB SPL-A)
- **Less proximity effect:** More consistent tone off-axis and at varying distances
- **Tighter polar patterns:** More directional, better rejection

**Construction:**
- Smaller capsule (6mm-18mm diameter)
- Usually fixed pattern (cardioid most common)
- Matched pairs common (stereo recording)
- Often transformerless design (lower noise)
- Pencil form factor typical

**Frequency Response:**
- Very flat: 20Hz-20kHz (minimal coloration)
- Extended highs: Some models to 25kHz+
- No presence peaks: accuracy over character
- Slight low-end roll-off: natural in small diaphragm design

**Applications:**
- **Acoustic instruments:** Guitar, mandolin, violin, banjo (accuracy)
- **Cymbals and hi-hats:** Detailed, clear, accurate reproduction
- **Piano:** Stereo pair captures full instrument (clarity and detail)
- **String sections:** Accurate ensemble capture
- **Percussion:** Fast transient response
- **Overhead drums:** Detailed cymbal reproduction
- **Classical/orchestral:** Accuracy and precision required
- **Any source:** Where accuracy more important than character

**Famous Examples:**
- **Neumann KM184:** Industry reference standard, $699 each (professional studios)
- **AKG C451B:** Modern version of legendary C451, $449 (discontinued original highly sought)
- **Shure SM81:** Affordable studio standard, $349 (extremely versatile)
- **Rode NT5:** Excellent value matched pair, $429/pair (home studios)
- **DPA 4011:** Ultra-accurate, expensive, $1,150 (classical recording)
- **Sennheiser e914:** Live and studio use, $599 (rugged design)
- **Schoeps CMC6/MK4:** Ultimate accuracy, modular, $1,400+ (classical, film)

**Typical Specifications:**
- Sensitivity: -36dBV/Pa to -40dBV/Pa (similar to large diaphragm)
- Max SPL: 130-140dB without pad, 145-150dB with pad
- Frequency Response: 20Hz-20kHz (flat ±2dB)
- Impedance: 50-200Ω (very low)
- Self-noise: 5-15dB SPL-A (very quiet)
- Polar pattern: Cardioid fixed (some switchable models)

**Advantages:**
- Most accurate frequency response
- Fastest transient response
- Extended high frequency
- Lowest self-noise
- Consistent off-axis response
- Excellent for stereo techniques

**Disadvantages:**
- Less character/warmth than large diaphragm
- Can sound clinical (too accurate)
- More expensive than dynamics
- Requires phantom power
- Fragile like all condensers

**Professional Uses:** Classical recording standard. Drum overheads. Acoustic instruments. Any application where accuracy and speed crucial. Matched pairs for stereo recording (X/Y, ORTF, spaced pair).

---

*[Content continues in Part 2 with Ribbon Microphones and additional microphone types]*

sections.title: Ribbon Microphone
sections.text:
**Technology/Operating Principle:**
Thin metal ribbon (aluminum typically, 2 microns thick - thinner than human hair) suspended in strong magnetic field. Sound pressure causes ribbon to vibrate → ribbon movement creates voltage through electromagnetic induction. Responds to **air velocity** not pressure (differentiates from dynamics/condensers).

**Construction:**
- Ultra-thin ribbon element (aluminum, sometimes duraluminum or nanofilm)
- Strong permanent magnets (neodymium typically, very powerful)
- Transformer (steps up voltage, matches impedance)
- Protective grille (screens ribbon from wind/pops)
- Figure-8 pattern natural to design (both sides of ribbon exposed)

**Key Characteristics:**
- **Smooth, natural sound:** No harshness or edginess
- **Warm tonal quality:** Gentle high-frequency roll-off (natural)
- **Figure-8 pattern inherent:** Picks up front and back, rejects sides
- **Very low output:** Requires excellent preamp (60-70dB gain needed)
- **Fragile (vintage):** Can be damaged by shock, wind, phantom power
- **Modern ribbons:** More robust (some phantom-safe with active electronics)
- **No proximity effect in theory:** But practical designs have some

**Frequency Response:**
- Extended low end: Excellent bass response (30Hz and below)
- Smooth midrange: Very flat, natural
- Rolled-off highs: Natural above 12-15kHz (not a deficiency, part of character)
- No resonant peaks: Exceptionally smooth response curve

**Output Level:**
- Sensitivity: -54dBV/Pa to -60dBV/Pa or lower (much lower than dynamic)
- Requires: Excellent low-noise preamp with high gain capability
- Cloud Microphones Cloudlifter: Popular inline gain booster for ribbons
- Modern active ribbons: Built-in amplifier (higher output, phantom-powered)

**Applications:**
- **Vocals:** Smooth, intimate sound (especially male vocals, broadcast)
- **Guitar amplifiers:** Tames harshness, warm and smooth
- **String sections:** Warm, natural reproduction
- **Brass instruments:** Smooth out harsh overtones (trumpets, trombones)
- **Room microphones:** Smooth ambient capture
- **Drum overheads:** Warm cymbal sound
- **Any harsh source:** Needing smoothing and warmth

**Famous Examples:**

**Passive (Traditional):**
- **Royer R-121:** Modern standard for guitar amps, $1,295 (studio workhorse)
- **AEA R84:** Affordable ribbon, classic sound, $1,095 (great value)
- **Coles 4038:** BBC standard since 1950s, vintage sound, $1,695 (drums, orchestral)
- **Beyerdynamic M160:** Hypercardioid ribbon, $599 (drums, brass)
- **RCA 44/77-DX:** Vintage legends, $3,000-8,000 (collectors, museums)

**Active (Modern, Phantom-Powered):**
- **Royer R-122:** Active version of R-121, +12dB output, $1,595
- **AEA R44C:** Active version of RCA 44 design, $2,495
- **sE Electronics VR1/VR2:** Modern active ribbons, $499-699
- **Cascade Fathead II:** Active ribbon, affordable, $349

**Vintage Ribbon Care:**
- **Never use phantom power:** Can permanently damage ribbon element
- **Handle gently:** Avoid dropping, shock
- **Protect from wind:** Even breath can damage ribbon
- **Store upright:** Ribbon can sag if stored horizontally long-term
- **High-pass filter:** Use to protect from low-frequency rumble

**Modern Ribbons:**
- Phantom-power safe (most)
- More robust construction
- Some with active electronics (higher output)
- Nanofilm ribbons (stronger than aluminum)

**Typical Specifications:**
- Sensitivity: -54 to -60dBV/Pa (very low, need lots of gain)
- Max SPL: 130-145dB (depending on model, actually quite high)
- Frequency Response: 30Hz-15kHz typical (smooth roll-off)
- Impedance: 200-300Ω output (after transformer)
- Pattern: Figure-8 naturally (some models cardioid through design)
- Self-noise: N/A for passive (active models: 12-18dB SPL-A)

**Advantages:**
- Smoothest, most natural sound
- No harshness or edge
- Extended low-frequency response
- Excellent transient response
- Vintage character (highly sought)

**Disadvantages:**
- Very low output (needs excellent preamp)
- Fragile (vintage models especially)
- Limited high-frequency extension
- Figure-8 pattern not always ideal
- Expensive (quality models)

**Professional Wisdom:** "Ribbon mics make everything sound better." Often true - inherently smooth response. Perfect for taming harsh sources. Guitar amp staple. Requires investment in good preamp.

---

sections.title: Boundary Microphone (PZM - Pressure Zone Microphone)
sections.text:
**Technology:** Microphone element mounted very close to boundary surface (wall, floor, table). Uses boundary effect - no phase cancellation from reflected sound (capsule within 1/4 wavelength of surface).

**Design:** Omnidirectional or hemispherical pickup. Capsule facing down toward boundary plate. Typically condenser element.

**Characteristics:**
- No comb filtering from boundary reflections
- Clear, phase-coherent sound
- Hemispherical pickup pattern (half-sphere)
- Good for room/ambient capture
- Low profile (unobtrusive)

**Applications:** Conference rooms (on tables), stage floors (theater, orchestra), piano sound boards, room mics, kick drums (sometimes placed inside).

**Famous Models:** Crown PZM-30D ($299), Audio-Technica AT871R ($149), Shure MX393 ($279).

---

sections.title: Shotgun Microphone (Interference Tube)
sections.text:
**Technology:** Super-directional microphone using interference tube. Tube with slots causes sounds from sides to cancel through phase interference. Front sound arrives coherently.

**Pattern:** Very narrow pickup (lobar pattern), extreme front rejection, excellent side/rear rejection.

**Characteristics:**
- Highly directional (narrowest pattern available)
- Long interference tube (short tube = less directional)
- Used at distance (3-10+ feet)
- Picks up reflected sound (not magic - still gets room)

**Applications:** Film/video production (boom mic), wildlife recording, sports broadcasting, any distant source isolation needed.

**Famous Models:** Sennheiser MKH 416 ($999 - industry standard film), Rode NTG3 ($699), Audio-Technica AT875R ($169).

**Professional Note:** Not for studio/music recording typically. Designed for dialog and effects capture in film/TV.

---

sections.title: Lavalier/Lapel Microphone
sections.text:
**Design:** Tiny microphone clipped to clothing. Usually omnidirectional (rejects handling noise). Condenser element (small size requires condenser).

**Characteristics:**
- Very small (discreet)
- Omnidirectional typically
- Consistent level (doesn't move)
- Requires wireless transmitter usually
- Professional models wired (broadcast)

**Applications:** Broadcast (news, interviews), theater (actors), presentations, film (hidden on actors), lectures.

**Famous Models:** DPA 4060 ($629 - pristine sound), Countryman B6 ($349 - industry standard), Sennheiser ME 2 ($99 - affordable).

---

sections.title: USB Microphone
sections.text:
**Design:** Microphone with built-in A/D converter and USB output. Connects directly to computer (no audio interface needed).

**Characteristics:**
- All-in-one solution
- No interface required
- Usually condenser type
- Built-in headphone monitoring (some models)
- Limited expandability (can't add more mics easily)

**Applications:** Podcasting, streaming, voice-over, home recording (simple setups), zoom calls.

**Popular Models:**
- Blue Yeti ($129 - popular, versatile, multi-pattern)
- Audio-Technica AT2020USB+ ($149 - studio quality)
- Rode NT-USB ($169 - podcasting standard)
- Shure MV7 ($249 - podcast/broadcast quality, dynamic)

**Advantages:** Simple setup, portable, affordable complete solution.
**Disadvantages:** Limited to one mic, cannot expand, interface quality varies, not professional studio use.

---

sections.title: Tube Microphone
sections.text:
**Technology:** Condenser microphone using vacuum tube (valve) in signal path instead of FET.

**Characteristics:**
- Warm, smooth sound (even-order harmonic distortion)
- Vintage character
- Requires external power supply (not just phantom power)
- Slow warm-up time (tubes need heating)
- Maintenance required (tube replacement eventually)

**Applications:** Vocals (warmth and character), anything needing vintage sound, adding harmonic richness.

**Famous Models:**
- Neumann U47 (vintage): $8,000-15,000 used (Beatles era)
- Telefunken ELA M 251E: $10,000+ (vintage classic)
- Warm Audio WA-47jr: $499 (affordable tube sound)
- AKG C12VR: $3,699 (reissue of C12 classic)

---

sections.title: Multi-Pattern Microphone
sections.text:
**Technology:** Multiple capsules or switchable polarization voltage. Can change between polar patterns (cardioid, omni, figure-8, and intermediate).

**Common Patterns:** Cardioid, Omni, Figure-8, and intermediate positions (wide cardioid, hypercardioid).

**Switching:** Physical switch on mic body OR remote control via cable.

**Applications:** Versatility (one mic for multiple applications), stereo techniques (M/S recording), matching recording technique to situation.

**Famous Models:**
- AKG C414 (9 patterns, $1,099 - extremely versatile)
- Neumann U87 (3 patterns, $3,200 - studio standard)
- Audio-Technica AT4050 (3 patterns, $699 - affordable multi-pattern)

---

sections.title: Cardioid Pattern (Heart-Shaped)
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Heart-shaped pickup. Most sensitive at front (0°), Rejection at rear (180° typically -20 to -30dB).

**Sensitivity by Angle:**
- **0° (directly front):** 0dB (maximum sensitivity, 100%)
- **45° (off-axis):** -3dB (70.7% sensitivity)
- **90° (directly to side):** -6dB (50% sensitivity)
- **135° (back-side):** -12dB (25% sensitivity)
- **180° (directly rear):** -20 to -30dB (3-10% sensitivity, maximum rejection)

**Pickup Arc:** Approximately 130° in front (within -6dB)

**Characteristics:**
- Most common pattern
- Good front/rear discrimination
- Rejects sound from behind
- Some side pickup
- Proximity effect present (bass boost when close, 6-12dB at 100Hz within 6 inches)
- Balanced off-axis response

**Applications:**
- **Live vocals:** Rejects stage monitors behind performer
- **Studio vocals:** Isolates from room reflections behind
- **Instrument close-micing:** Isolates from other instruments
- **Any situation:** Needing rear rejection
- **General purpose:** Most versatile pattern

**When to Use:**
- Monitor speakers positioned behind microphone
- Need isolation from other sources
- Want to reduce room sound
- Standard recording situation

**Proximity Effect Management:**
- Strong when <6 inches (6-12dB bass boost at 100Hz)
- Can be used creatively (warmth, "radio voice")
- Can be problem (too boomy)
- Solution: High-pass filter OR back off microphone

**Famous Cardioid Mics:** SM57, SM58 (industry standards), U87 (cardioid mode), most studio mics.

---

sections.title: Supercardioid Pattern
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Tighter front lobe than cardioid. Some rear pickup (not full rejection). Maximum rejection at 120-150° off-axis (not directly behind).

**Sensitivity by Angle:**
- **0° (front):** 0dB (maximum)
- **45°:** -4dB (narrower than cardioid)
- **90° (side):** -9dB (better side rejection than cardioid)
- **120-150°:** -12 to -15dB (null points, maximum rejection)
- **180° (rear):** -6dB (some rear pickup - cannot ignore)

**Pickup Arc:** Approximately 115° in front (narrower than cardioid)

**Characteristics:**
- Narrower than cardioid
- Better side rejection
- More rear pickup than cardioid (-6dB at rear vs -20dB)
- Maximum rejection at 125° (not rear)
- More proximity effect than cardioid
- More critical aiming (narrower pattern)

**Applications:**
- **Live sound:** Better feedback rejection (tighter pattern)
- **Loud stages:** More isolation from nearby sources
- **Multiple sources close together:** Better separation
- **Handheld vocals:** Tighter control, less handling noise
- **Can tolerate:** Slight rear pickup (monitors at 125° null point)

**When to Use:**
- Need maximum gain before feedback
- Very loud stage/environment
- Multiple close sources (drum mics)
- Want tighter pickup than cardioid
- Can position monitors at null points (120-150°)

**Monitor Placement:** Place monitors at 125° off-axis (null points), NOT directly behind (has rear pickup).

**Versus Cardioid:** Tighter front pickup, Better side rejection, More rear pickup (trade-off).

**Famous Supercardioid Mics:** Shure Beta 57A/58A, Sennheiser e935, Audix OM5.

---

sections.title: Hypercardioid Pattern
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Even tighter than supercardioid. More rear pickup. Maximum rejection at 110° off-axis.

**Sensitivity by Angle:**
- **0° (front):** 0dB
- **45°:** -5dB
- **90° (side):** -12dB (excellent side rejection, better than super/cardioid)
- **110°:** Maximum rejection (null point)
- **180° (rear):** -6dB (significant rear pickup, same as supercardioid)

**Pickup Arc:** Approximately 105° in front (narrowest of cardioid family)

**Characteristics:**
- Narrowest pickup (without being shotgun)
- Best side rejection
- Most rear pickup of cardioid family
- Requires precise aiming
- Maximum proximity effect
- Professional applications

**Applications:**
- **Theater:** Dialog pickup, reject side stage noise
- **Film boom:** Tight dialog isolation
- **Very loud stages:** Maximum front isolation
- **Specific pickup needed:** When precision critical
- **Can accept rear pickup:** In controlled situations

**When to Use:**
- Maximum isolation from front needed
- Can work with rear pickup
- Extremely loud environment
- Very precise aiming possible
- Professional controlled environment

**Monitor Placement:** At 110° off-axis (null points), NEVER directly behind (significant rear pickup).

**Versus Supercardioid:** Even tighter front, Even better side rejection, Same rear pickup, More critical positioning.

**Famous Hypercardioid Mics:** Shure SM7B (broadcast standard), AKG D112 (kick drum), Sennheiser MD 421 (variable between super and hyper).

---

sections.title: Omnidirectional Pattern
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Sphere. Picks up equally from all directions.

**Sensitivity by Angle:**
- **All directions:** 0dB (±1dB, essentially equal)
- **No rear rejection:** Picks up everything equally
- **No null points:** Cannot reject from any direction

**Characteristics:**
- Equal pickup all directions
- No off-axis coloration (sounds same from any angle)
- No proximity effect (no bass boost when close)
- Most natural sound
- Captures room acoustics fully
- No feedback rejection (picks up monitors)

**Frequency Response:** Flattest possible (no off-axis effects, no proximity effect).

**Applications:**
- **Room microphones:** Capture natural ambience
- **Orchestral recording:** Main pickup (natural, even)
- **Measurement:** Acoustic measurement (true response)
- **Situations where room sounds good:** Capitalize on acoustics
- **Multiple sources:** When want natural blend
- **Classical music:** Accurate ensemble capture

**When to Use:**
- Room acoustics are good
- Want most natural sound
- Need consistent response all directions
- No proximity effect desired
- Controlled acoustic environment

**When NOT to Use:**
- Live sound (feedback issues)
- Need isolation (picks up everything)
- Bad-sounding room (captures all reflections)
- Multiple sources need separation

**Advantages:**
- Most natural, accurate sound
- No coloration from direction
- No proximity effect (consistent bass)
- Extended low frequency (no pattern-related roll-off)

**Disadvantages:**
- No isolation (picks up everything)
- Room sound dominant
- Not feedback-resistant
- Cannot control what's picked up

**Famous Omni Mics:** DPA 4006 (classical recording), Earthworks QTC40 (measurement), Neumann KM 184 (omni capsule).

**Professional Uses:** Classical/orchestral recording (main pair), Room mics (when room sounds excellent), Measurement and testing, Acoustic research.

---

*[Content continues in Part 3 with Figure-8, Shotgun patterns, and Micing Techniques]*

sections.title: Figure-8 (Bidirectional) Pattern
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Figure-eight or infinity symbol (∞). Equal pickup front and back. Complete rejection at sides (90° and 270°).

**Sensitivity by Angle:**
- **0° (front):** 0dB (maximum)
- **45°:** -3dB
- **90° (side):** -∞dB (complete null, total rejection)
- **135°:** -3dB
- **180° (rear):** 0dB (equal to front)
- **270° (side):** -∞dB (complete null)

**Characteristics:**
- Picks up equally front and back
- Complete side rejection (nulls at 90° and 270°)
- Natural to ribbon microphones
- No proximity effect theoretically
- Can be used for rejection

**Applications:**
- M/S stereo recording (side mic)
- Blumlein pair (two figure-8s at 90°)
- Rejection from sides (position source at null)
- Duets (two performers facing each other)
- String sections (capture front and ambient rear)

**Famous Figure-8 Mics:** Royer R-121 (ribbon), AEA R84 (ribbon), all ribbon mics naturally.

---

sections.title: Shotgun (Lobar) Pattern
sections.text:
**Pattern Shape:** Extremely narrow elongated pattern. Very tight front pickup. Maximum reach.

**Characteristics:**
- Narrowest pattern available
- Long reach (can be used at distance)
- Extreme side/rear rejection
- Uses interference tube
- Best at distance (3-10+ feet)

**Applications:** Film/video (boom), wildlife recording, sports, distant isolation.

**Famous Shotgun Mics:** Sennheiser MKH 416, Rode NTG3, Audio-Technica AT897.

---

sections.title: Switchable/Multi-Pattern
sections.text:
**Technology:** Multiple capsules or variable voltage allows pattern switching.

**Common Patterns Available:** Cardioid, Omni, Figure-8, and intermediate positions.

**Advantages:** Versatility (one mic, multiple uses), Can match pattern to situation, Essential for stereo techniques.

**Famous Multi-Pattern Mics:** AKG C414 (9 patterns), Neumann U87 (3 patterns), AT4050 (3 patterns).

---

sections.title: Close Micing (Proximity Micing)
sections.text:
**Distance:** 1-12 inches from source.

**Advantages:**
- Maximum isolation from other sounds
- Reduced room acoustics
- More intimate/direct sound
- More gain before feedback (live)
- Control over sound

**Disadvantages:**
- Strong proximity effect (bass boost)
- Less natural sound
- Highly positional (small movement = big tone change)
- Misses room ambience
- Can emphasize flaws

**Applications:** Live sound, drum kit, guitar/bass amps, isolation needed.

**Technique:** Angle mic to control tone. High-pass filter for proximity effect. Use 3:1 rule with multiple mics.

---

sections.title: Distance Micing (Ambient Micing)
sections.text:
**Distance:** 1-15+ feet from source.

**Advantages:**
- Natural, realistic sound
- Room acoustics included
- Less proximity effect
- Position less critical
- Captures space

**Disadvantages:**
- Less isolation
- More room sound
- Lower direct-to-ambient ratio
- Phase issues with close mics

**Applications:** Acoustic instruments, orchestral, room mics, good-sounding rooms.

**Technique:** Listen in room first, place mic where sounds best.

---

sections.title: 3:1 Rule (Distance Rule)
sections.text:
**Guideline:** Distance between mics should be at least 3× distance from mic to source.

**Example:** Mic 4" from snare → next mic minimum 12" away.

**Why:** Minimizes phase cancellation, maintains level differences over time differences.

**Application:** Drum micing, multi-mic recordings, any multiple mics on sources.

---

sections.title: Phase Checking
sections.text:
**Process:** Solo individual mics → Add second mic → If thinner sound: phase issue.

**Solutions:**
- Phase invert button (flip polarity 180°)
- Time alignment (slide region)
- Microphone repositioning

**Critical:** Top/bottom snare, multiple drum mics, stereo techniques, room with close mics.

---

sections.title: Kick Drum - Inside
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic designed for bass (AKG D112, Shure Beta 52A, Audix D6)
**Position:** Inside drum, 2-6 inches from beater
**Distance:** Close = attack, Far = boom
**Angle:** At beater = attack, Off-side = tone
**Dampening:** Blanket common
**Hole:** Remove front head or cut hole
**Multiple:** Inside (attack) + outside (tone)

sections.title: Snare Drum - Top
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic (SM57 standard, Audix i5, Sennheiser e604)
**Position:** 1-2" above rim, aimed at center, 45° angle
**Distance:** 1-2" = attack, 3-4" = more body
**Angle:** Straight down = ring, Angled = crack
**Phase:** Check with overheads/other mics

sections.title: Snare Drum - Bottom
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condenser
**Position:** Under snare, aimed at snares
**Phase:** Invert (usually opposite top)
**Purpose:** Snare wire detail, crack

sections.title: Hi-Hat
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condenser (KM184, SM81, NT5)
**Position:** 4-6" above, edge, angled down
**Aim:** Away from snare (reduce bleed)
**Distance:** Farther = less harsh

sections.title: Overhead Cymbals
sections.text:
**Technique:** Stereo pair (X/Y, ORTF, or spaced)
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condensers (matched pair)
**Height:** 3-5 feet above kit
**Position:** Over drummer's head or slightly forward
**Balance:** Equal distance to snare (mono compatibility)

sections.title: Toms
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic (Sennheiser MD421, Audix D2/D4)
**Position:** 1-2" above head, aimed at center
**Angle:** 45° toward center
**Distance:** 1-2" from rim

---

sections.title: Acoustic Guitar
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small/large diaphragm condenser
**Position 1 - 12th Fret:** 6-12", balanced tone (most common)
**Position 2 - Sound Hole:** Warmer, more bass (watch for boom)
**Position 3 - Bridge:** Brighter, more attack
**Stereo:** 12th fret + bridge
**Distance:** 6-12" typical

sections.title: Electric Guitar Amp
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic (SM57 standard) or ribbon (smooth)
**On-Axis:** Directly at speaker center (brightest, aggressive)
**Off-Axis:** At edge of cone (warmer, less harsh)
**Distance:** 1-6" (closer = tighter)
**Dual Mic:** SM57 on-axis + ribbon off-axis
**Room Mic:** 10-20 feet for space

sections.title: Upright Bass
sections.text:
**Mic:** Large diaphragm condenser or ribbon
**Position:** 6-12" from f-hole or bridge
**Height:** Mid-body
**Distance:** 1-2 feet for natural

sections.title: Violin/Viola
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condenser
**Position:** 1-2 feet, aimed at f-holes
**Height:** Slightly above instrument
**For ensemble:** Further back (3-5 feet)

sections.title: Cello
sections.text:
**Mic:** Large diaphragm condenser
**Position:** 1-2 feet from f-holes
**Angle:** Slightly above

---

sections.title: Studio Vocals
sections.text:
**Mic:** Large diaphragm condenser (U87, C414, AT4050)
**Distance:** 6-12" typical
**Pop Filter:** Essential, 6" from mic
**Pattern:** Cardioid (isolation) or omni (natural, treated room only)
**Height:** Mouth level, slight downward angle
**Room:** Reflection-free zone essential

sections.title: Live Vocals
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic (SM58, Beta 58A, e935)
**Distance:** 2-6" (proximity effect for warmth)
**Pattern:** Cardioid or supercardioid
**Handling:** Handheld, on stand

sections.title: Choir/Group Vocals
sections.text:
**Mic:** Large diaphragm condensers, stereo pair
**Distance:** 5-10 feet
**Pattern:** Cardioid or omni
**Placement:** Above and in front

---

sections.title: Saxophone
sections.text:
**Mic:** Large diaphragm condenser or ribbon
**Position:** 6-12" from bell
**Angle:** Slightly off-axis (on-axis harsh)

sections.title: Trumpet/Brass
sections.text:
**Mic:** Dynamic or ribbon (tame harshness)
**Position:** 1-2 feet from bell, off-axis
**Ribbon:** Smooths harsh overtones

sections.title: Flute
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condenser
**Position:** Above and slightly behind mouthpiece
**Distance:** 6-12"

sections.title: Clarinet
sections.text:
**Mic:** Small diaphragm condenser
**Position:** Mid-body, angled toward keys
**Distance:** 8-12"

---

sections.title: Grand Piano - Classical
sections.text:
**Technique:** Stereo pair, lid fully open
**Mics:** Small/large diaphragm condensers
**Position:** Inside, 8-12" above strings
**Distance:** 6-12" from hammers
**Stereo:** Spaced pair or ORTF

sections.title: Grand Piano - Pop/Rock
sections.text:
**Technique:** Close micing, lid on short stick
**Position:** Inside, closer to strings
**Goal:** More attack, presence, separation

sections.title: Upright Piano
sections.text:
**Position:** Back removed, mics behind
**Alternative:** Above open top, through soundboard holes

---

sections.title: X/Y (Coincident Pair)
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two cardioid mics, same point, 90-135° angle
**Characteristics:** Perfect phase coherence, mono compatible
**Stereo Width:** Moderate
**Applications:** Acoustic guitar, piano, orchestral
**Advantage:** No phase issues

sections.title: M/S (Mid-Side)
sections.text:
**Setup:** Cardioid facing forward (mid), figure-8 sideways (side)
**Decoding:** M+S = Left, M-S = Right
**Advantages:** Mono compatible, adjustable width in post
**Width Control:** Adjust side level for width
**Applications:** Mastering, acoustic instruments, flexibility needed

sections.title: Spaced Pair (A/B)
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two mics (usually omni), 3-10 feet apart
**Spacing:** Depends on source size
**Characteristics:** Wide stereo image, spacious
**Phase:** Check in mono
**Applications:** Orchestra, drum overheads, large sources

sections.title: ORTF
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two cardioids, 17cm apart, 110° angle
**Origin:** French broadcasting standard
**Characteristics:** Wider than X/Y, phase coherent
**Applications:** Orchestra, acoustic ensembles, film

sections.title: Decca Tree
sections.text:
**Setup:** Three omnis: center forward, L/R 2m apart angled out
**Height:** Above conductor/ensemble (10-15 feet)
**Purpose:** Main classical orchestral pickup
**Additional:** Spot mics on sections
**Characteristics:** Wide, natural, spacious

sections.title: Blumlein Pair
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two figure-8 mics at 90° (crossed)
**Characteristics:** Natural, spacious, accurate
**Mono:** Compatible (adds coherently)
**Applications:** Classical, jazz, ambient

sections.title: NOS (Nederlandse Omroep Stichting)
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two cardioids, 30cm apart, 90° angle
**Origin:** Dutch broadcasting
**Similar to:** ORTF but different spacing/angle
**Applications:** Broadcast, orchestral

sections.title: Spaced Omnis (Wide Spaced Pair)
sections.text:
**Setup:** Two omnis, 6-15 feet apart
**Characteristics:** Very wide, spacious
**Phase:** Issues in mono
**Applications:** Orchestra, large ensemble, room

---

sections.title: Electromagnetic Induction (Dynamic)
sections.text: Voice coil attached to diaphragm moves in magnetic field. Moving conductor through magnetic field generates voltage (Faraday's law). Voltage proportional to velocity of diaphragm. Simple, rugged, passive design. No power required. Less sensitive than condenser.

sections.title: Variable Capacitance (Condenser)
sections.text: Two plates form capacitor: diaphragm (movable) and backplate (fixed). Fixed charge applied (via phantom power or permanent). Diaphragm movement changes capacitance. Capacitance change creates voltage change. Requires power and active electronics. Very sensitive, accurate.

sections.title: Pressure vs Velocity
sections.text: **Pressure:** Responds to sound pressure (dynamic, condenser). **Velocity:** Responds to air particle velocity (ribbon). Velocity = naturally bidirectional (figure-8). Pressure = can be any pattern.

sections.title: Diaphragm Mass and Size
sections.text: **Large Diaphragm (≥1"):** More mass, slower transient response, warmer character, lower self-noise per area. **Small Diaphragm (<1"):** Less mass, faster transients, more accurate, extended highs.

sections.title: Transducer Principles
sections.text:
**Moving Coil:** Electromagnetic induction. **Capacitor:** Variable capacitance. **Ribbon:** Electromagnetic induction (velocity). Each has unique character and applications.

---

sections.title: Pop Filter
sections.text: Fabric screen preventing plosives (p, b, t sounds). Distance: 4-6" from mic. Essential for vocals. Reduces wind blast. Does NOT affect frequency response significantly.

sections.title: Shock Mount
sections.text: Suspends mic in elastic bands/springs. Isolates from handling noise and vibration. Essential for: sensitive condensers, floor/stand vibrations. Reduces: low-frequency rumble.

sections.title: Windscreen/Foam
sections.text: Foam cover reducing wind noise. Outdoor recording essential. Reduces: plosives slightly. Minimal frequency response effect. For heavy wind: blimp/zeppelin needed.

sections.title: Mic Stand Types
sections.text:
**Boom:** Horizontal extension (most versatile)
**Straight:** Vertical only
**Desktop:** Short, stable
**Overhead:** Tall for drums

sections.title: XLR Cables
sections.text:
Balanced 3-pin: ground, hot, cold. Rejects interference (common-mode rejection). Professional standard. Can be very long (100+ feet). Quality matters: shielding, connectors.
